ChatGPT said:

Excellent — I’ll begin researching how the Great Awakening transformed American Protestantism into a competitive, market-based sectarian system, with attention to transatlantic influences and its relationship to later movements like Seventh-day Adventism.

I’ll focus on itinerant revivalism, breakdown of parish authority, denominational competition, revival-based fundraising and media networks, and the ideological links to later missionary and sectarian innovation. I’ll let you know when the research package is ready.

Great Awakening and the Birth of Competitive American Protestantism

The First Great Awakening and the Rise of America’s Religious Marketplace

Introduction

In the mid-18th century, a wave of evangelical revivals swept through the American colonies, shattering old structures of religious life and transforming Protestant Christianity. This era, known as the First Great Awakening (c. 1730s–1740s), broke down the traditional parish-based authority of state churches and ushered in a new “marketplace” of religionnewyorker.com. Charismatic itinerant preachers like George Whitefield and Jonathan Edwards bypassed established clergy and appealed directly to masses of listeners, emphasizing individual conversion (“new birth”) over institutional tradition. In their wake, a proliferation of competing denominations – Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians, and others – vied for followers in a newly free religious economy. Ordinary colonists, including women and the working class, seized unprecedented roles in this revitalized religious sphere, eroding old hierarchies in favor of a more democratic, sectarian Christianityamericanheritage.org. The Awakening’s innovations – use of mass media and print, itinerant circuits, emotional appeal, and grassroots fundraising – not only invigorated American religion at home but also laid cultural foundations for the missionary and reform movements that soon stretched across the Atlantic world. This report examines how revivalism during the First Great Awakening created a consumer-choice model of faith, fostered market competition between Protestant sects, and ultimately inspired new religious movements (from 19th-century Adventists and Shakers to Jehovah’s Witnesses) as the long tail of American religious entrepreneurship. Key evidence, timelines, and scholarly perspectives (Weber, Hatch, Heyrman, etc.) are provided to illuminate this transformative period in religious history.

Timeline of Revival and Sectarian Growth (1730–1900)

  • c.1700–1730: Colonial churches are mostly established denominations (Congregational in New England, Anglican in the South) with formal parish systems. Church attendance is declining by the 1730s amid Enlightenment influencesen.wikipedia.org.

  • 1734–1735: Jonathan Edwards leads a local revival in Northampton, Massachusetts. He reports the town “never was so full of Love, nor so full of Joy, nor so full of distress as it has lately been”en.wikipedia.org, as many experience conversion. This revival, described in Edwards’s A Faithful Narrative, gains transatlantic attention.

  • 1739–1741: George Whitefield’s Grand Tour. English evangelist Whitefield preaches from Georgia to New England, drawing massive intercolonial crowds. He ignores parish boundaries, “preached wherever possible… in church halls, streets, and marketplaces,” attracting thousands with his dramatic oratoryamericanheritage.org. Revival fires ignite across the colonies (notably, 1740–42).

  • 1741: Old Lights vs. New Lights: The revival splits denominations. In July 1741, Edwards delivers “Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God.” In May 1741, the Presbyterian Synod expels pro-revival New Side ministers, formalizing a schismen.wikipedia.org. Debates rage between revival advocates (New Lights) and traditionalists (Old Lights) over emotionalism and itinerancy.

  • 1740s: “Separatist” offshoots form. Many New Light Congregationalists in New England break away to form separate Separate Congregations or join the Baptists, who accept only adult baptism. Entire Separatist churches convert to Baptist principles; by 1804 over 300 Baptist churches exist in New England, up from only a handful before the Awakeningen.wikipedia.org. In 1746, New Light Presbyterians found the College of New Jersey (Princeton) to train evangelical ministersen.wikipedia.org.

  • 1760s–1770s: Revivalism spreads to the South. New Light Baptists (e.g. Shubal Stearns’s Separate Baptists) carry evangelical religion into Virginia and the Carolinas, challenging the Anglican establishment. Enthusiastic preaching draws “significant numbers of Baptists… in the Southern Colonies” despite legal harassmenten.wikipedia.org. 1770: George Whitefield dies, but by now he is “the single best-known religious leader in America of [the 18th] century”americanheritage.org, having made seven preaching tours and unified many colonies in shared revival experience.

  • 1770s–1780s: American Revolution and Disestablishment. After Independence (1783), states begin to disestablish official churches (Virginia in 1786, others by 1830s). The end of state religion creates a free market of religion where denominations must attract voluntary members rather than rely on tax supportchristianhistoryinstitute.org. Evangelical sects benefit in this entrepreneurial environment.

  • 1784: Methodist Church organized in America. Under John Wesley’s approval, American Methodists separate from the Anglican Church. Leaders like Francis Asbury establish a network of itinerant circuit riders who will bring Methodism to the frontiers. This sets the stage for explosive post-1800 growth.

  • 1790s–1830s: Second Great Awakening builds on First. Camp meetings (e.g. Cane Ridge, 1801) and urban revivals renew mass enthusiasm. Methodists and Baptists surge to become the largest US denominations by the 1830schristianhistoryinstitute.org. Parachurch societies (Bible societies in 1810s, missionary boards, etc.) form, exporting revivalist Protestantism abroad.

  • 1840s: Millerite Movement and Adventism. Preacher William Miller’s nationwide revival campaign (1830s–1844) predicts Christ’s return in 1844, rallying tens of thousands in an apocalyptic fervor (a product of the Second Awakening’s climateen.wikipedia.org). The failure of Miller’s prediction in the “Great Disappointment” (Oct 1844) leads followers to splinter into new sects – notably the Seventh-day Adventist Church (formalized 1863) which retains Miller’s Advent hope but adds distinctive doctrines (Saturday Sabbath, prophetic guidance of Ellen G. White). Millerites also influence future founders of the Jehovah’s Witnesses, another sect that would emerge by the 1870s out of Adventist Bible-study circles.

  • 1774–1800s: Shakers in America. A radical pietist sect begun by Mother Ann Lee in England (1747) arrives in New York in 1774. The Shakers (United Society of Believers in Christ’s Second Appearing) establish communal, celibate settlements. In the Kentucky frontier revival of 1800–01, some Presbyterians convert to Shakerism, seeing in it “the apotheosis of that alternate community” promised by revival – “a camp meeting that never ended.”digitalcommons.wku.edu Despite hostility from mainstream churches, Shaker communities spread through the early 19th century, demonstrating how revival enthusiasm could birth new utopian sects.

Breaking Down Parish Authority: Itinerants vs. the Establishment

Before the Awakening, colonial religion was rooted in parish churches bolstered by law and tradition. Each community had its sanctioned minister, and religious life was orderly, if sometimes sterile. The revivalists turned this world upside-down. George Whitefield, an Anglican itinerant, epitomized this shift. Nicknamed the “Grand Itinerant,” Whitefield became “the first man to travel up and down the east coast… reaching and preaching in all thirteen colonies”americanheritage.org. Disregarding parish boundaries, he preached wherever crowds gathered – fields, barns, town squares – often to thousands at a timeamericanheritage.org. Such itinerancy defied the authority of settled pastors and alarmed many traditional clergy.

Critics like Boston minister Charles Chauncy decried these roaming preachers as interlopers who “offered sensationalist theater as religious experience” and lured people away from their home churchesnationalhumanitiescenter.org. Yet the response of the populace showed that the old parish model was weakening. Farmer Nathan Cole of Connecticut famously described how, upon hearing Whitefield was to preach nearby, he “dropt my tool…and ran to my pasture for my horse with all my might” to ride 12 miles to the meetinghistorymatters.gmu.eduhistorymatters.gmu.edu. He and his wife raced alongside scores of others: “the Cloud [of dust] was a Cloud of dust made by the Horses’ feet… every horse seemed to go with all his might to carry his rider to hear news from heaven for the saving of Souls. It made me tremble… how the world was in a struggle”historymatters.gmu.edu. Cole saw the roads choked with people “all pressing forward in great haste… I saw no man at work in his field, but all seemed to be gone.”historymatters.gmu.eduhistorymatters.gmu.edu Such scenes – fields and farms emptied for revival gatherings – dramatize how laypeople voted with their feet, abandoning daily routine and local pews to follow the electrifying itinerants.

By undermining deference to the local ordained minister, the Great Awakening eroded the old parish monopoly on religious life. New Lights contended that many officially installed ministers were themselves unconverted. As revivalist Gilbert Tennent warned in 1740, an unregenerate pastor was a blind guide leading people astray (“The Danger of an Unconverted Ministry”). This sentiment justified bypassing established clergy in favor of direct encounters with the Spirit. Traditional clergymen “found themselves increasingly under threat”newyorker.com as revivalists urged people to seek salvation outside the formal church channels if necessary. In short, the Awakening broke the exclusive authority of state-sanctioned churches, creating a more fluid, voluntary religious environment. No single church could any longer claim automatic loyalty of the populace; people would go where the spiritual fire was. As historian John Howard Smith notes, the Great Awakening made sectarianism – a patchwork of rival faith groups – “an essential characteristic of American Christianity.”en.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org

The Rise of Itinerant Revivalists: Whitefield, Edwards and the New Evangelists

The Awakening’s new religious landscape was shaped in large part by the personalities and methods of its leading itinerant revivalists. George Whitefield and Jonathan Edwards stood out, though they differed in style. Whitefield, only in his mid-20s during his American tours, was a theatrical orator who could spellbind crowds of thousands with his dramatic gestures, tears, and exuberant message of rebirth. “Appealing to all denominations… [this] ‘Divine Dramatist’ attracted huge crowds,” and possessed a “loud, clear voice” that could carry to the back of throngsamericanheritage.orgamericanheritage.org. He preached the necessity of a conscious conversion experience – being “born again” – and insisted that “every person—regardless of class, wealth, education, or prestige—could freely choose Jesus Christ.”americanheritage.org This was a radically egalitarian spiritual message in a stratified society. Even critics conceded Whitefield’s magnetic appeal; contemporary Ben Franklin (no devout churchman himself) wrote “it was wonderful to see the change… one could not walk thro’ the town in an evening without hearing psalms sung in different families of every street.”americanheritage.org Whitefield became colonial America’s first celebrity preacher, famous up and down the seaboard, and arguably “the best-known religious leader in America” of the 18th centuryamericanheritage.org. By making revival preaching inter-colonial – transcending local confines – he helped knit the geographically scattered colonies into a more cohesive cultural unit, a fact noted by observers who saw in 1740 that Whitefield “turned the Christian revival into an inter-colonial or ‘national’ movement.”americanheritage.org

Jonathan Edwards, by contrast, was a settled Congregational minister and theologian in Northampton, MA, whose influence spread through his powerful writing and theology. Edwards’s revival in 1734–35, though confined to one region, became a model: he published A Faithful Narrative of the events, which circulated widely in America and Britainen.wikipedia.org. It portrayed vivid conversions and communal transformations, giving revivalists a template for what to expect. Edwards defended the conversion hysteria (swoons, cries, visions) that sometimes accompanied the revivals, so long as it led to genuine repentanceen.wikipedia.org. In his famous sermon “Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God” (1741), Edwards combined terrifying imagery of divine judgment with an urgent call to experience God’s mercy – a classic of revivalist rhetoric that reportedly had listeners moaning and clinging to pews in fear of hell. While Edwards was more intellectual than Whitefield, he too affirmed the Awakening’s core idea: that true religion is a matter of the heart’s experience of grace, not mere adherence to forms. “Being truly religious meant trusting the heart rather than the head, prizing feeling more than thinking,” as Christine Leigh Heyrman summarizes the evangelical ethosnationalhumanitiescenter.org. This was a sharp departure from the cool, rational Calvinism many colonial ministers had settled into.

Both Whitefield and Edwards, and dozens of lesser-known preachers (Gilbert Tennent, Samuel Davies, James Davenport, etc.), ignited a contagious revival fervor. Their itinerancy and publications created an interconnected network of revival knowledge. Whitefield’s tour of 1740, in particular, was “one of the most remarkable episodes in the whole of American Christianity” and “the key event of the Great Awakening,” according to historian Mark Nollamericanheritage.org. By spreading a common evangelical message up and down the colonies, these men fostered a new kind of pan-Protestant consciousness. Denominational lines blurred at revival meetings: Anglicans, Presbyterians, Baptists, Congregationalists would all gather to hear the same sermon. This unprecedented cross-pollination planted the seeds for both unity and division – unity in the shared “born-again” experience that believers of different churches now claimed, but division as many then questioned the validity of churches or ministers who lacked that experience. Thus, the stage was set for sectarian realignment and competition.

Sectarian Competition and the “Consumer” Model of Religion

By the end of the First Great Awakening, American Protestantism had become a dynamic pluralism of sects. The collapse of any one church’s dominance gave rise to a de-facto religious free market. Individuals could, for the first time on a large scale, choose among multiple denominations – a “marketplace of religion” took shape in America where “winning over converts took precedence” over enforced loyaltynewyorker.com. Churches now had to compete for adherents through attractive preaching, promises of spiritual renewal, and accessible organizations. In effect, revivalism turned religion into a matter of consumer choice rather than birthright or state assignment.

Nowhere was this more evident than in the phenomenal rise of Baptists and Methodists, two upstart evangelical sects that leveraged revival methods to grow exponentially. “The Baptists benefited the most from the Great Awakening,” notes one historyen.wikipedia.org. Prior to 1740, Baptists were a tiny, often-persecuted sect in New England. But as revival fervor led some Congregationalists to question infant baptism and embrace believer’s baptism, whole Separatist congregations became Baptist. By 1804 New England boasted 300+ Baptist churches (where a century earlier there were scarcely any)en.wikipedia.org. In the South, similarly, Baptist preachers won converts among common folk, including enslaved Africans, by preaching an emotional, simple gospel of salvation and performing adult immersions. The Methodists had a slightly later start in the colonies (as disciples of John Wesley, they organized after the Revolution), but once unleashed, their growth outpaced all others. With a system of itinerant circuit riders reaching into every frontier hamlet, the Methodists “carried out the most successful church-planting campaign in American history” between the Revolution and Civil Warchristianhistoryinstitute.orgchristianhistoryinstitute.org. By the 1830s, Methodist and Baptist churches were the fastest-growing in the nation, outstripping the older denominations (Congregationalists, Anglicans/Episcopalians, Presbyterians)ushistory.org. Indeed, by the mid-19th century, Methodism was the largest Protestant denomination in the country – a remarkable ascent for a movement that had been marginal in the First Awakeningchristianhistoryinstitute.org. The Baptists were not far behind, even dominating in parts of the South and on the frontierchristianhistoryinstitute.org.

This sectarian competition was fueled by the revival ethos. Because evangelicals insisted that true faith comes from a personal decision (to be converted and “born again”), they inherently fostered a voluntaristic religious culture. No one’s salvation was presumed by birth or parish; one had to choose and could therefore also choose which group’s approach to follow. Rival denominations, all preaching variants of evangelical Protestantism, vied to offer the most compelling path to salvation. This was noted by sociologist Max Weber, who observed that in America’s pluralistic setting, churches had to operate akin to businesses in competition, adapting their practices to attract and retain members. A “free market of religion” rewarded those groups that were nimble, fervent, and in tune with the masseschristianhistoryinstitute.org. As one scholar puts it, “Direct tax support for churches was out; entrepreneurial religion was in. The American free market of religion benefited nimble evangelical denominations, especially the Methodists and the Baptists.”christianhistoryinstitute.orgchristianhistoryinstitute.org In other words, the collapse of old church monopolies after the Awakening (and legally after disestablishment) meant religious entrepreneurship became the norm. Preachers had to compete for souls; success was measured in conversion numbers and new congregations formed, much like market share.

Along with competition came innovation in religious practice. Evangelical sects introduced populist styles to appeal to the “consumer.” For example, sermons became more emotional and entertaining (Whitefield’s dramatic flair set the tone), music more lively (the rise of revival hymns), and worship more participatory (with converts giving testimonies, lay exhorters praying, etc.). Protracted revival meetings and camp meetings were essentially spiritual “sales” events, where preachers from different groups might all set up tents and vie for attendees. Some historians have likened the scene to a religious bazaar offering choices for all tastes. Indeed, as early as the 1740s, one observer quipped that the number of rival preachers and sects meant that “religion has become such a thing of fashion that people strive to be converted as if buying a new suit of clothes.

Of course, sectarian competition was not only market-driven but also born of genuine theological disputes. The Awakening caused schisms: the Presbyterian Church split into New Side vs Old Side (1741–1758) over revivalismen.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org; Congregationalists split into New Lights vs Old Lights; many dissatisfied New Lights then joined Baptists or formed independent “Separatist” churches when shut out by the establishmenten.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org. These splits meant multiple denominations now coexisted in the same towns, ending the idea of one parish, one people. By encouraging plurality, the revival movement ensured that America would henceforth be a land of sectarian diversity. “The Great Awakening made sectarianism an essential characteristic of American Christianity,” as historian J. H. Smith observeden.wikipedia.org. Church membership became a matter of personal conviction and voluntary association, a profound shift from the earlier era of inherited church allegiance.

Print, Media, and “Holy Advertising”: Revivalism’s New Methods

The First Great Awakening coincided with – and skillfully exploited – the rise of print capitalism and media networks in the 18th century. Revivalists were early religious entrepreneurs in print, using newspapers, pamphlets, and journals to spread their message and build intercolonial followings. George Whitefield’s partnership with Benjamin Franklin is a striking example. Franklin, Philadelphia’s prominent printer, admired Whitefield’s oratory and helped disseminate it: he printed Whitefield’s sermons and journals and ran announcements of his meetings in the Pennsylvania Gazette. The two even arranged a subscription service for Whitefield’s writingsamericanheritage.org. Through these means, news of revivals and conversion narratives traveled far beyond the immediate vicinity. One contemporary noted that early revivals remained local until “the lack of coverage in print media” was overcome; after 1730s, widespread publicity turned local awakenings into regional and transatlantic eventsen.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org. Whitefield became a master of what today we might call religious marketing. He was known to use “media and the marketplace” to enhance his reach: “he used media like the new colonial newspapers and market advertising to spread the Christian Gospel and to raise publicity for his tours.”americanheritage.orgamericanheritage.org This was a novelty – earlier ministers had not advertised religion in the public square. By doing so, Whitefield filled town commons and churchyards with eager crowds.

Print not only gathered crowds; it also unified the revival movement’s identity. Publications like Edwards’s revival accounts or the many sermons and tracts that flew off colonial presses created a shared narrative of conversion. The written word could cross the ocean: Edwards’s Faithful Narrative was published in London (with the help of evangelicals like Isaac Watts) and influenced revival sympathizers in Englanden.wikipedia.org. Soon British evangelicals (the Wesley brothers, etc.) were corresponding with American ones – a true transatlantic religious network enabled by print. The itinerant preachers often left a trail of printed sermons, pamphlets, and newspaper reports in their wake, which in turn inspired others to seek the same experiences. In a sense, print was the technology that scaled revivalism beyond what one man could do in person.

Another important medium was the periodical press. Magazines and newspapers carried both glowing accounts and harsh critiques of the Awakening. This public debate kept religion in the popular consciousness. For example, between 1740 and 1748, virtually every newspaper in New England and the Middle Colonies reported on Whitefield’s tour or the ensuing controversiesdigitalcommons.pepperdine.edu. This was an early form of mass media religious publicity, prefiguring the religious press boom of the 19th century.

Fundraising was another arena of innovation. Revivalists and their new institutions had to fund their activities without state support. They turned to the public. Whitefield, notably, raised money during his sermons for an orphanage in Georgia; Franklin recounts emptying his coin purse under the spell of Whitefield’s fundraising plea despite intending not to give (anecdote from Franklin’s Autobiography). Whitefield also sold his journals and advocated for charitable subscription schemesamericanheritage.org. Thus, he pioneered a kind of evangelical fundraising appealing directly to lay donors – a practice that would become standard for later missionary societies and Bible societies. In effect, revivalists learned to sustain their ministries through voluntary donations and print sales, an early form of what we might call crowdfunding. This was in stark contrast to the tax-based revenue of established churches. It made religious leaders accountable to their audiences (contributors), further shifting power toward the lay public.

The revival movement’s embrace of popular media and marketing had lasting effects on American Christianity. It introduced what one historian calls “innovative techniques, media, and the marketplace” into evangelismamericanheritage.org. No longer would American ministers rely solely on austere sermons to a captive audience; now they had to attract audiences. Whitefield’s success “changed expectations and demands for church leaders. Previously church congregations sought leaders with formal training and traditional orthodoxy. Now they looked for leaders with emotion, enthusiasm, and charisma.”americanheritage.org In other words, the communicative and promotional savvy that revivalists displayed set a new bar for religious leadership. The charismatic revival preacher – often self-taught, entrepreneurial, and media-savvy – emerged as a rival model to the old learned parish parson. This democratization of media access meant any preacher with a compelling story and printing press could potentially reach the whole nation (or at least all the colonies).

As a result, one can see the Awakening as not just a spiritual upheaval but a communications revolution in religion. Historian Frank Lambert dubbed Whitefield a “Pedlar in Divinity” – a nod to his skill in hawking the gospel through print and performance. The synergy of revival religion with the rising commercial print culture meant that American faith would henceforth be disseminated through books, tracts, and eventually the vast Christian publishing industry of the 19th century. Print capitalism thus supercharged revivalism, turning local preachers into celebrities and religious choices into widely advertised “products.”

Democratization of Religious Authority and Lay Participation

One of the most radical legacies of the First Great Awakening was the democratization of religious authority. The revivals empowered groups previously excluded from leadership – laymen without formal education, young people, women, even enslaved and indigenous converts to some extent – to take active roles in the religious community. The stress on “new birth” experience leveled the spiritual playing field: in God’s eyes, the illiterate farmhand’s heartfelt conversion was as valid as the Harvard-trained minister’s doctrine. This translated into greater assertion of laypeople’s spiritual authority and a questioning of the old clergy-dominated order.

Lay preachers and exhorters became common. In the heat of revival meetings, it was not unusual for unordained men (and occasionally women) to rise and share testimonies, exhort the crowd, or lead impromptu prayer. The Methodist movement particularly made use of lay preachers. John Wesley and George Whitefield, finding the work too large for ordained clergy alone, “appointed lay preachers and leaders” to sustain Methodist societies on both sides of the Atlanticen.wikipedia.org. These were often tradesmen, farmers, or artisans who felt called to ministry and were given basic guidance but no formal seminary training. The idea that passion and devotion mattered more than credentials was a direct product of revival values. It was scandalous to many at first – one Anglican bishop complained of “mechanicks preaching” – but it proved immensely successful in reaching common folk. As Mark Noll notes, “The Puritan ideal of the minister as an intellectual and educational leader was steadily weakened in the face of the evangelical ideal of the minister as a popular crusader and exhorter.”newyorker.com In other words, charisma trumped credentials. This shift effectively democratized who could lead: if you had the Spirit’s anointing (as evidenced by success in winning souls), people would follow you, degree or no degree.

Women, while barred from formal pastorates in all major denominations of the 18th century, found new avenues for religious influence through revivalism. Churches reported that women often formed the majority of converts in revival meetings. They hosted prayer gatherings in homes, shared conversion stories, and some (like Sarah Osborne in Rhode Island or later Phoebe Palmer in the 19th century) became renowned as teachers and writers on revival spirituality. During the Awakening itself, a few women even took on public roles: in 1742, for instance, Sarah Parsons Moorhead published a scathing poem rebuking a wayward revival preachernationalhumanitiescenter.org, showing that women, too, engaged in the public religious discourse the revival generated. Furthermore, as historian Christine Heyrman observes in the southern context, early evangelical movements deliberately “insinuated themselves into white households through their most vulnerable and receptive members – women and youth.”jsr.fsu.edu Young people and wives, hungry for a more heartfelt faith, were often the first in their families to convert, thereby pressuring fathers and husbands to follow. In this way, the revivals quietly undercut patriarchal religious control, at least for a time. Enthusiastic young preachers (sometimes themselves teenagers or in their early 20s) “troubled the waters of domestic life” by appealing to the spiritual longing of women and the discontent of sonsjsr.fsu.edujsr.fsu.edu. Evangelical religion thus offered a kind of social levelling: the Spirit could speak through the commoner or the daughter, not just the gentleman or the ordained clergyman.

Among the working classes and marginalized groups, the Awakening had a similarly democratizing (and galvanizing) effect. The message that all souls are equal in salvation encouraged people of lower status to assert their place in the congregation. Baptist and Methodist churches in the revival tradition were notably more welcoming to the poor and socially humble than the old colonial churches had been. Some of the most zealous New Light preachers (such as Shubal Stearns or “Uncle” Daniel Marshall among Separate Baptists) were not educated elites, and they deliberately dressed plainly and spoke in the dialect of ordinary folks, in contrast to the learned Latin-quoting pastors of the establishment. Nathan Hatch, in The Democratization of American Christianity, argues that this populist thrust only accelerated after the Revolution: “the theme of democratization is central to understanding the development of American Christianity”, and it was the era from 1780–1830 – the immediate aftermath of the first revivals – that “left as indelible an imprint upon the structures of American Christianity as… upon American political life.”academia.edu The implication is that the Revolution in politics and the “revolution” in religion went hand in hand, each pushing greater empowerment of ordinary people. The Great Awakening was the opening salvo in that religious democratization.

It is worth noting that not all scholars agree on how purely “democratic” the revivals were. Nathan Hatch celebrates the way evangelicals “empowered the unlettered and the unschooled” to shape Christianityacademia.edu. But Christine Leigh Heyrman offers a nuanced view: she cautions that calling the evangelical surge a straightforward “democratization” misses the social conflicts involved. Heyrman argues that early Southern Baptists and Methodists gained influence partly by exploiting social disturbances and fears (e.g. fears of damnation, of disorder) and initially attracted those marginalized (women, youth) in ways that threatened traditional authorityjsr.fsu.edujsr.fsu.edu. Over time, however, these sects moderated and even retrenched in hierarchy – by the 1830s, evangelicals in the South began catering to adult male authority and even defending slavery to gain respectabilityjsr.fsu.edujsr.fsu.edu. In Heyrman’s view, the movement was radical in its youth and more conservative in its maturity, suggesting that the democratizing impulse was real but constrained. This scholarly debate underscores that the Awakening’s legacy included both a genuine leveling of religious access and the seeds of new forms of authority.

Nonetheless, the immediate legacy was that religious life in America was no longer the domain of a learned few. The average person’s spiritual judgment and experience were validated. A New Light writer in 1743 exulted that “even a poor negro or boy that can scarce speak sense” might speak words that convert sinners if inspired by God – a hyperbolic way of saying God could use anyone. This ethos later fueled movements like the licensing of lay exhorters, the proliferation of local Bible societies and missionary volunteers (including many women), and the sense that “ordinary people… in the early republic were the most critical force” in Christian expansionacademia.edu.

Additionally, the Awakening brought some racial democratization, though limited: For the first time, significant numbers of African Americans were exposed to evangelical religion. Some were swept up in the revival fervor – in the 1740s, evangelist Samuel Davies in Virginia reported converting slaves and even training a few black exhorters. In the 1770s, freedmen George Liele and David George became pioneering black Baptist preachers, founding Baptist churches among slaves in the South and later in Nova Scotia and Jamaicachristianhistoryinstitute.orgchristianhistoryinstitute.org. The early biracial revivals had a leveling effect in worship (whites and blacks singing and praying together, which was astonishing for that society) and planted the seed for independent black denominations (Richard Allen, a black convert of Methodist revivals, would found the African Methodist Episcopal Church by 1816)christianhistoryinstitute.org. While full equality was far off and many white evangelicals would compromise with racism, the initial revivals nonetheless communicated a radical notion: in the eyes of God, “All men are equal before God” (a phrase popular among New Lights)americanheritage.org. This spiritual egalitarianism resonated with the ideals of the later American Revolution and broadened the base of religious leadership beyond old ethnic and class lines.

In summary, the First Great Awakening greatly pluralized and democratized religious authority. It took religious initiative out of the sole hands of educated clergy and spread it among the populace – a shift with profound implications for American culture. As one scholar put it, by awakening a sense of “freedom in religious affairs,” the revivals helped Americans assume that they could shape their own churches, a mindset that “configured similar feelings in politics.”nationalhumanitiescenter.org The empowered evangelical individual (choosing faith according to conscience) was a precedent to the empowered democratic citizen (choosing leaders and beliefs freely). It is no accident that so many early American sects championed religious liberty and the separation of church and state, fighting remaining establishment laws in the 1760s–1780s. The Awakening had made religion a matter of voluntary conviction, and as such, the idea of a state-coerced faith became untenable. In that sense, revivalism was a mighty engine driving American ideas of individual rights and the consent of the governed in spiritual matters – a true religious parallel to the political Enlightenment.

Transatlantic Connections: The British Revival and American Uniqueness

While our focus is on American developments, it’s important to note that the First Great Awakening was part of a broader transatlantic evangelical revival. In Britain, a contemporaneous movement often called the Evangelical Revival or Methodist Revival was underway, led by John Wesley, Charles Wesley, and George Whitefield (who operated on both sides of the ocean). This means the American revivals did not occur in isolation; rather, they were linked with revival currents in England, Scotland, Wales, and beyond.

Whitefield himself is the best example of this linkage. An English Anglican by ordination, he had been a member of John Wesley’s “Holy Club” at Oxford. His revivals in England (open-air preaching to coal miners in Kingswood, for example) in 1739 preceded and inspired his American touren.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org. John Wesley, too, after his transformative “heart-warming” experience in 1738, took up field preaching across England, forming Methodist societies. Whitefield invited Wesley to take over the work in Georgia for a time, and they corresponded frequently. Thus, there was a constant flow of ideas and personnel across the Atlantic. Whitefield’s print publicity in America was matched by similar tactics in England – in London he drew crowds of 30,000 and used newspaper ads to promote meetingsen.wikipedia.org. The Moravians (German pietists) were another transatlantic influence: Moravian missionary presence in Georgia and the Wesleys’ contact with them infused the revival with pietistic spirituality (prayer circles, hymn-singing, emotional devotion) that influenced both continentsen.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org.

Despite these commonalities, there were differences. In Britain, the revival remained (for a time) more within the framework of the Church of England. John Wesley never intended to form a separate church during his lifetime; he created an evangelical movement inside Anglicanism (Methodist “societies” that met weekly for prayer and Bible study, while members still attended their parish church for sacraments). This was possible because the Church of England, though initially hostile to “enthusiasm,” eventually tolerated a space for evangelical clergy and lay Methodists. In America, by contrast, the lack of a single dominant church (apart from regional establishments) and the eventual disestablishment meant that Methodism and other sects quickly became separate denominations. American Methodists formally split from Anglicanism in 1784, as noted, whereas British Methodism did not officially separate until after Wesley’s death. Also, America’s pluralism was more pronounced even before the Awakening – the colonies had a variety of sects (Quakers, Dutch Reformed, German Lutherans, etc., especially in the Middle Colonies) competing on “equal terms”en.wikipedia.org. So one could say the “free market” of religion had early seeds in the colonies, but the Great Awakening greatly expanded and energized it.

Another distinction was geographic: The American revivals swept a society that was also on the edge of the frontier (and soon expanding west), whereas Britain’s revival occurred in an old society beginning to industrialize. Thus, after 1750 the trajectories diverge – American revivalism kept pushing west with the population, becoming a force of expansion and nation-building, while British evangelicals (like William Wilberforce and the Clapham Sect) turned energies toward social reform at home (abolition of slavery, etc.) and global missions abroad. The Second Great Awakening in the US (1800s) had no real parallel in Britain; by that time, British evangelicalism was more institutionalized and less given to mass camp-meetings.

Yet the two sides always remained in dialogue. American revival publications were read in Britain and vice versa. The transatlantic character of the First Awakening is well-captured by the career of Whitefield: he “was English, yet he was also the most important figure in the revivals in America, Scotland, and Wales.”christianhistoryinstitute.org He and others effectively made it a single Anglo-American phenomenon – a fact often noted by historians. It’s said that the First Great Awakening was a fully integrated Anglo-American event, in contrast to the Second which was distinctly Americanchristianhistoryinstitute.org. Revival letters crossed the ocean; British Baptist Anne Dutton corresponded with Edwards; American converts’ stories appeared in English devotional literature. This exchange of revival accounts helped spread a common evangelical identity across the English-speaking world.

In the end, however, the American context allowed revivalism to have a more sweeping structural impact. By breaking the churches’ ties to the state and multiplying sects, the Awakening in America paved the way for what observers like Alexis de Tocqueville (visiting in 1831) would marvel at: a country teeming with religious energy and voluntary religious societies of every stripe. In England, the established church remained, and dissenting sects, though energized by revival, did not achieve dominance. One might say that in Britain, evangelical revival renewed the Church (within Anglicanism and Methodism eventually) and gave rise to important dissenting growth, but did not fully invert the religious system. In America, it practically did.

To sum up, the First Great Awakening was part of a broader transatlantic revival movement, sharing figures and ideas with Britain and Europe (even Continental pietists). However, its outcome in America – a highly competitive, plural, market-driven Protestant landscape – was distinct. The New World proved to be fertile soil for the freest expression of revivalist, sectarian religion, whereas in the Old World revivalism remained somewhat contained by older institutions. This is why scholars often emphasize American exceptionalism in religion: the confluence of revivalism with republican liberty produced something novel – a society where religion flourished by competition and choice, not by decree.

The Long Tail of Revivalism: Sectarian Innovators and Religious Entrepreneurship

The First Great Awakening set in motion forces that would echo through American religious history for generations. Its logic of revival and religious “entrepreneurship” – the idea that new light and new revelation could break forth, that new communities of believers could organize around fresh interpretations – led to a proliferation of new sects and movements well into the 19th century. In many ways, later groups like the Shakers, Seventh-day Adventists, and Jehovah’s Witnesses (among others) can be seen as the “long tail” of revivalist ideology: they carried revivalism’s emphasis on personal revelation, charismatic leadership, and competition with mainstream churches to new extremes, carving out distinct niches in the religious marketplace.

The Shakers (officially the United Society of Believers in Christ’s Second Appearing) offer an early example. Born directly out of the 18th-century transatlantic revivals, the Shakers began with Mother Ann Lee, a visionary woman in England who, amid a Quaker revival in 1747, claimed to receive special revelations. Ann Lee and a small band of followers (who earned the nickname “Shaking Quakers” for their ecstatic worship style) emigrated to America in 1774, seeking religious liberty. They arrived in New York and soon attracted converts in the tumultuous Revolutionary era. The Shakers embraced radical doctrines: celibacy, communal living, pacifism, and a belief that Ann Lee was a female embodiment of Christ’s spirit (hence “Second Appearing”). These were bold departures from orthodox Christianity, and yet Shakerism gained adherents especially after the Second Great Awakening revivals. In the great Kentucky revival of 1800–01, some revival enthusiasts found the Shaker message (with its promise of a pure millennial community) compelling. By 1807, a Shaker village was established at South Union, Kentucky, composed largely of former Presbyterians who had been at the Cane Ridge camp meetingsdigitalcommons.wku.edudigitalcommons.wku.edu. One historian noted that for those converts, “The Great Revival was a brief… escape from chaos. Shakerism offered the apotheosis of that alternate community – [a] camp meeting that never ended.”digitalcommons.wku.edudigitalcommons.wku.edu In other words, Shaker villages institutionalized the revivalist dream of a perfect, Spirit-filled society. The Shakers spread through the Northeast and West, creating about 20 settlements at their height. Their success was limited (they never exceeded a few thousand members), and their strict celibacy meant they relied on conversions to grow. Still, their very emergence demonstrates the propensity of American revival religion to spin off new sects that challenged mainstream doctrine. Shakers used intense itinerant missionary efforts – often two by two, echoing the evangelical itinerants – to recruit converts. They also deftly used print (publishing tracts and songs) to explain their unusual beliefs. In the “market” of American religion, the Shakers positioned themselves as offering a higher purity and prophetic leadership than the churches around them – an ultimate extension of revivalism’s claim that established churches had grown cold.

Moving into mid-19th century, the Adventist movement continues the pattern. While not a direct product of the 1740s Awakening, the Adventist movement’s roots lie in the revival fervor of the Burned-Over District (western New York) in the 1830s and 1840s – itself a region heavily influenced by earlier waves of revival. Preacher William Miller was a Baptist layman who, inspired by intense Bible study, calculated that Christ would return in 1843–1844. His message spread like wildfire during the 1840s, attracting tens of thousands across denominational lines – an interdenominational revival focused on end-times prophecy. This Millerite movement can be seen as a kind of “ultra” revival: it urged people to immediate conversion and preparation for the imminent Second Coming. When October 22, 1844, passed without the expected event (the infamous “Great Disappointment”), Miller’s following was devastated. However, not all disbanded; in the freewheeling religious economy of America, some followers regrouped and reinterpreted the prophecy (saying Christ had begun a heavenly judgment phase rather than a visible return). From these came the Seventh-day Adventists, who formally organized in 1863. They incorporated revivalist features: they held fervent camp meetings, emphasized heartfelt conversion, and added distinctive doctrines (like Saturday Sabbath observance and dietary rules), effectively differentiating themselves in the market. A young visionary woman, Ellen G. White, emerged as their prophetic leader, claiming divine visions – much as earlier revivalists claimed the Spirit’s direct guidance. The Adventists grew, in true entrepreneurial fashion, by establishing an extensive publishing operation (the Review and Herald press), founding schools and health institutions, and aggressively sending missionaries abroad. By the late 19th century, the Seventh-day Adventist Church had become a global religious entrepreneur, taking America’s revival-born faith to Africa, Asia, and beyond – an “export” of revivalist Christianity.

From the Millerite milieu also came influences on the Jehovah’s Witnesses. Charles Taze Russell, who founded what became the Witnesses in the 1870s, was deeply influenced by Adventist teachers (he attended Advent Christian lectures and was mentored by Adventist writers like George Storrs)en.wikipedia.orgmultiversum.com.ua. Russell took the revivalist impulse in another direction: he rejected mainstream churches entirely as corrupt and, much like earlier sectarians, started a Bible study group that sought to rediscover “true” Christianity from scripture alone. In 1879 he launched Zion’s Watch Tower, a religious journal to disseminate his teachings – again, the print-first strategy of revival entrepreneurs. By 1884, he incorporated the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society, effectively creating a new denomination through print and preaching circuits. The group (later called Jehovah’s Witnesses) adopted Adventist-influenced doctrines (non-Trinitarianism, end-times millenarianism) and is notable for its rigorous house-to-house evangelism – a modern analog to the itinerancy of Whitefield or Asbury, but now every member is an itinerant of sorts, going door to door. The Witnesses’ growth in the late 19th and 20th centuries – from a small sect to a worldwide movement – underscores how the legacy of revivalist voluntarism and marketing continued. They offered an alternative to both traditional churches and even to other revivalist groups, carving out a unique theological niche (e.g. denying hell, predicting end-time dates repeatedly). In the competitive religious marketplace, they thrived by zealous proselytism and voluminous publishing (the Watchtower magazine). In many ways, they epitomize the ongoing sectarian innovation that the First Awakening set in motion: an approach where religious leaders act as entrepreneurs, believers become missionaries, and new organizations proliferate by highlighting how they differ from the religious status quo.

Other sects could be mentioned – the Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints), for example, sprang from the same Burned-Over District revivals and combined charismatic revelation (Joseph Smith’s visions) with entrepreneurial institution-building, resulting in a major new religion. Though the user didn’t list them, Mormons are a prime example of revivalist logic (continuous revelation, new scripture, gathering of a new chosen people) taken to its own outcome. Spiritualist movements (like those that flourished in the 1850s, communicating with the dead) also drew energy from the democratized religious sphere, as did utopian communities (Oneida, etc.). The key point is that the floodgates of American religious experimentation, opened in the mid-18th century, never really closed. Sectarian groups keep emerging, each testing the market for spiritual “consumers” dissatisfied with existing options.

Max Weber’s insights help us understand this phenomenon: he wrote that American sects, lacking state aid, had to prove their worth through members’ commitment and worldly success, fostering a kind of sanctified competition that paralleled capitalist enterprise. Indeed, Weber saw the voluntary Protestant sect as a crucible for the “spirit of capitalism” – it demanded discipline, fostered social networks of trust (because membership vouched for one’s moral reputation), and had to continuously attract and retain adherents through persuasion and performanceen.wikipedia.org. The byproduct was a highly adaptive and innovative religious culture, one that could spawn new movements when older ones no longer met needs. As one modern historian observed, “Revivalism changed the nature of Protestant Christianity. Religious faith became more individualistic and less tethered to institutional authority; immediate experience took priority over tradition. A marketplace of religion took shape in America”newyorker.com. In such a marketplace, entrepreneurs of faith like Ann Lee, William Miller, or Charles T. Russell could find space to offer “new and improved” spiritual paths – and sometimes win a following.

Finally, the missionary and global export dimension must be noted. The organizational and cultural tools developed in the post-Awakening competitive environment – fundraising societies, volunteer missionary organizations, printed propaganda, itinerant circuits – were readily applied to foreign missions by the late 18th and early 19th centuries. America’s First Awakening gave birth to the first missionary college (Dartmouth, 1754) aimed partly at converting Native Americansen.wikipedia.org. By the 1810s, American evangelicals (Congregationalist, Presbyterian, Baptist, Methodist, etc.) formed mission boards to send preachers abroad – notably the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions (founded 1810) and otherschristianhistoryinstitute.org. These efforts were built on the revivalist passion to “win souls” and the practical know-how of mobilizing people and money. The global missionary enterprise can be seen as an “export industry” of American revivalism: having succeeded in “Christianizing America” through competitive zealchristianhistoryinstitute.orgchristianhistoryinstitute.org, these religious activists turned to Christianize the world. They sent itinerant evangelists across the Pacific, Bibles translated into new tongues, and set up schools and churches in Asia, Africa, and the Pacific – all practices perfected on the frontiers of Kentucky or New England. This missionary legacy is another facet of how the First Great Awakening’s influence extended far beyond the 1740s, shaping a global outreach ethos that remains strong in American churches.

Conclusion

The First Great Awakening was a watershed that transformed American Protestantism from a patchwork of cautious, state-aligned churches into a vibrant free-marketplace of faiths. Traditional parish authority and hierarchy gave way to voluntarism and sectarian diversity, as itinerant revivalists ignited a populist religious fervor that empowered ordinary people to choose (and propagate) their own forms of worship. In the Awakening’s aftermath, denominations proliferated – competing and innovating much like businesses in an open market – which led observers to note that American religion had become defined by “sectarianism” and competitionen.wikipedia.org. The revivals championed direct emotional religion and downplayed credentialed authority, meaning charisma and conviction trumped pedigree in the new religious ordernewyorker.com. Armed with print media, entrepreneurial tactics, and an anti-traditional zeal, revivalists set the template for American religious life: energetic, pluralistic, and often commercial in method if not in message.

The effects were wide-ranging. Internally, American Protestantism became far more democratic – responsive to lay influence and open to leadership from outside the old elites. As Nathan Hatch observed, the early Republic’s religious culture was indelibly shaped by this “empowerment of ordinary people” in matters of faithacademia.edu. Externally, the Awakening knit the colonies together and foreshadowed the idea of religious liberty that would be enshrined in the new nation’s principles. The collapse of enforced religion and rise of voluntary churches meant the state would eventually “get out of the religion business,” leaving it to the people – a profoundly important development for American identity.

Moreover, the revivalist ethos carried forward into the Second Great Awakening and beyond, fueling America’s 19th-century volunteer movements, from abolition and temperance to foreign missions – virtually all of which drew leadership and inspiration from evangelical ranks. And as we have seen, the “long tail” of revivalism includes some of America’s most distinctive religious innovations: Shakers dancing in ecstatic worship; Adventists calculating prophecy and promoting health reforms; fervent missionaries circling the globe; and modern evangelists harnessing new media (from the printing press in Whitefield’s day to radio/TV in the 20th century) to “sell” the old-time religion in ever-new ways.

The First Great Awakening thus stands as a critical chapter in the history of religion-as-free enterprise. It broke the mold of state-supported orthodoxy and proved that religious enthusiasm could thrive in a free, competitive environment – an insight later codified by sociologists and economists of religionchristianhistoryinstitute.org. Some contemporaries bemoaned this fragmentation and populism; Boston’s Charles Chauncy argued the revivals had filled churches with ill-regulated emotion and undermined clerical learning. Indeed, as Richard Hofstadter later pointed out, the awakeners “quickened anti-intellectualism” in American Christianitynewyorker.com, shifting emphasis from theological scholarship to heart religion. Yet even Chauncy would likely concede that by the eve of the American Revolution, the religious landscape had been forever altered: a person in, say, 1770 Virginia or New England might now have Baptist, Methodist, Presbyterian, or Separate options where once only the established church stood. Choice in religion became an American hallmark, for better or worse.

In sum, the First Great Awakening injected into American Protestantism a lasting competitive and innovative spirit. As one historian aptly put it, “Revivalism changed the nature of Protestant Christianity… Religious faith became more individualistic and less tethered to institutional authority; immediate experience took priority over tradition. A marketplace of religion took shape in America.”newyorker.com This 18th-century revolution in faith laid the groundwork for the pluralistic, dynamic religious culture that characterizes the United States to this day. Every new sect or movement that arises – from 19th-century holiness and Pentecostal revivals to 21st-century megachurches and televangelists – follows a trail blazed in the Great Awakening, when Americans first learned that they were free to choose how to worship, and ambitious preachers learned to compete for the privilege of leading them.

Sources:

  • Michael Luo, The New Yorker – analysis of the Great Awakening’s impact on anti-intellectualism and the rise of a religious marketplacenewyorker.comnewyorker.com.

  • American Heritage Foundation – on George Whitefield’s itinerancy, media use, and democratic evangelical styleamericanheritage.orgamericanheritage.org.

  • First Great Awakening (Wikipedia) – details on denominational splits and growth (Baptists, New Light vs Old Light, etc.)en.wikipedia.orgen.wikipedia.org.

  • Thomas Kidd, Christian History Magazine – discussion of disestablishment and free market of religion benefiting Methodists/Baptistschristianhistoryinstitute.orgchristianhistoryinstitute.org.

  • Steven Stowe (review of Christine Heyrman’s Southern Cross) – critique of the “democratization” thesis, highlighting evangelical conflict and appeal to women/youthjsr.fsu.edujsr.fsu.edu.

  • William R. Black, Went off to the Shakers (M.A. thesis) – on Kentucky revival’s role in Shaker conversionsdigitalcommons.wku.edudigitalcommons.wku.edu.

  • Primary sources: Nathan Cole’s narrative of 1740 (account of crowds rushing to hear Whitefield)historymatters.gmu.eduhistorymatters.gmu.edu; Jonathan Edwards’s letter (1737) on the Northampton revivalen.wikipedia.org; Benjamin Franklin’s description of the revival atmosphere in Philadelphiaamericanheritage.org; Christine Leigh Heyrman, Divining America essay (1997) – context on heart vs head in evangelical religionnationalhumanitiescenter.org.

  • Nathan Hatch, The Democratization of American Christianity – thesis on ordinary people’s empowerment in post-Awakening religionacademia.edu.

  • John Howard Smith via CLI/Christian Leaders – note on sectarianism as an essential trait after the Awakeningen.wikipedia.org.

  • Additional scholarly works as cited in-line above.

Revised U S. Part II – “Protestantism Unbound”

8The First Great Awakening (1730-1760): Faith Goes ViralRecap we just finished: itinerancy, print capitalism, consumer choice, lay empowerment.Launches the religious marketplace model.
9The Second Great Awakening (1800-1840): Charisma, Frontier, and Social ExplosionCamp-meetings, circuit riders, Arminian optimism, perfectionism. Birth of voluntarist mass-movement religion and the “burned-over” incubator for sect-building (Mormons, Adventists, Shakers, Spiritualists…).Shows Protestantism mutating into a charismatic, improvisational engine. Pairs nicely with later 1960s New Age for a “charisma vs. control” through-line.
10Slavery’s Gospel: Southern Baptists and the Theology of Mastery (1830-1865)How pro-slavery clergy forged the most authoritarian Protestant sub-culture: biblical literalism, racial hierarchy, paternalism. Why this works

  1. Narrative tension:
    Chs 9 & 12 = unruly, Spirit-driven, border-smashing Protestantism.
    Ch 10 = the exact opposite: rigid, hierarchical, state-serving theology.
    That dialectic sets up your later Cold-War chapter perfectly (religion weaponised for politics).

  2. Drops the bloated Progressive-Era detail (unless you want a quick pit-stop for Social-Gospel/corporate philanthropy facts).

  3. Makes room for a short “Islamic colonial” detour (Bábí/Baháʼí in Qajar Iran, Ahmadiyya in late-Raj India) without clogging the U S. arc; those can live just before or after the U S. chapters as a parallel case of prophetic succession & Western modernity.

Below is a “sanity-check” list of religious developments in the U S. between the Civil War and 1945 that historians usually flag as structural (not just background noise). Use it as a menu: if an item clearly advances your argument, keep it; if it doesn’t, jettison it with no guilt.

1. Otherwise you can fold two sentences of context into the Cold-War chapter and move on.
2. Holiness & early Pentecostalism (Wesleyan “Entire Sanctification,” Azusa Street 1906)A direct charismatic continuation of the Second Great Awakening: ecstatic gifts, interracial worship, women preachers, global missionary fire. Also births the worldwide Pentecostal family (Assemblies of God, Church of God, etc.).✔ if you need a charisma-lineage between 1830s frontier camp-meetings and 1960s New Age / Charismatic Renewal. Otherwise skip.
3. Fundamentalist – Modernist split (1900-1930, Scopes 1925)Evangelicals invent the “parallel sub-culture” strategy (Bible institutes, prophecy conferences, separatist missions) after losing public prestige; later re-enter politics as “neo-evangelicals” and then Religious Right.🔸 Useful only if you plan to explain why 1945 networks were already in place for anti-communist mobilization. If that’s covered in your Cold-War chapter, you can mention Scopes in a footnote and call it a day.
4. Mass-media ministries & consumer religion (Dwight Moody’s urban campaigns 1870s; Aimee Semple McPherson & radio 1920s)Perfects the technology+marketing toolkit that Billy Graham & televangelists later scale up.Same logic as #3. Could be one sidebar on “pre-1945 media experiments” or left out entirely.
5. Black Social-Gospel & Holiness churches (AME growth, Richard Allen legacy → W.E.B. Du Bois’s “The Black Church,” Marcus Garvey blending Pentecostal tongues with black nationalism)Shows how racialized America produced a separate institutional universe that will power Civil-Rights theology in the 1950s–60s (King inherits it).Keep if you want to argue that US religion’s “public-spiritual” vision always excluded black Americans, forcing them to build an alternative model. Otherwise your slavery-chapter may already make the point.
6. Immigrant Catholic & Jewish pluralism (Ellis Island wave, parochial-school system, Knights of Columbus, B’nai B’rith)Adds the demographic facts that by 1920s the U S. is no longer culturally Protestant, prompting nativist backlashes (second KKK, Prohibition).Optional context for why 20th-c. Protestant elites felt they were “losing America” — ammo for Cold-War Christian nationalism.

8. Ecumenical & bureaucratic mergers (Federal Council of Churches 1908 → National Council 1950)Shows Mainline Protestantism turning into a centralized policy lobby, the very structure that the World Council and UN chaplaincies slot into later.Keep only if you need to explain how liberal Protestants pivot smoothly into Cold-War internationalism.

Practical pruning advice

  • If your book’s spine is:
    “Awakening → Slavery Theology → Mormon Entrepreneurism → Cold-War Religious Machine,”
    then the only Progressive-Era threads that really earn page space are:

    1. a two-paragraph bridge on Social-Gospel corporatism (#1) to show how churches were already comfortable blending piety, philanthropy, and business;

    2. a one-paragraph nod that early Pentecostalism (#2) keeps the charisma current alive until it erupts again in 1960s Charismatic/New Age;

    3. maybe a sentence on Fundamentalist retrenchment (#3) as setup for post-1945 re-emergence.

  • Everything else can be footnotes or endnotes if readers want rabbit holes.

Why the Progressive-Era “Age of Mobilization” (≈ 1870-1945) still matters for your story

(and how Charles Taylor + Batnitzky help frame it)

What shiftsWhy it’s structurally newHow it supports your thesis that “religion-as-category” peaks here
Taylor’s “Age of Mobilization” (1800-1960, climaxing 1900-1940)Churches stop being birthright institutions and recruit, organize, and lobby like mass-membership parties, unions, or clubs Wikipedia.Religious identity hardens into voluntary, bounded “denominations” competing for members, cementing the idea of many “religions” rather than one public cultus.
Social-Gospel / church-as-service-providerUrban Protestants build settlement houses, hospitals, Y-MCA/Y-WCA, and articulate a “Social Creed” (Federal Council 1908) that aligns theology with Progressive public policy Wikipedia+1.This bureaucratic turn shows religion re-packaged as a sector (of welfare & reform) alongside business and government—exactly the compartmentalized model you critique.
Ecclesiastical bureaucracy & ecumenismCreation of the Federal → National Council of Churches (1908 → 1950) knits 30+ mainline bodies into a quasi-lobby Wikipedia.Demonstrates that by 1900 U S Protestants consciously treat themselves as one “interest group” among others in the public square.
Fundamentalist/Modernist split & mass-media revivalistsAfter 1910, evangelicals invent Bible institutes, prophecy conferences, and radio ministries to ring-fence “the fundamentals.” Aimee Semple McPherson turns religion into primetime entertainment by 1923 The Old New Way.Shows how rivals inside one tradition start behaving like separate “religions,” deepening the marketplace logic you traced from the Awakenings.
Early Pentecostalism (Azusa 1906)Inter-racial, women-led, ecstatic; spreads worldwide via faith missions. It is the charismatic fuse between 1830s camp meetings and 1960s New Age/Charismatic Renewal thearda.com.Keeps your “charisma stream” alive while institution-heavy mainlines are professionalizing—perfect for your later New-Age contrast.
Modern Jewish self-definitionLeora Batnitzky shows that only in the 19th-c. emancipation era did intellectuals rebuild Judaism as a religion (vs. peoplehood/law) to fit liberal nation-state categories Jewish Book Council.Provides a non-Christian corroboration: even Jews adopt the “religion box” precisely when the Protestant sector is professionalizing.
Japan parallelThe Invention of Religion in Japan (Josephson) argues Meiji elites likewise carved “religion” off from public Shinto rites to satisfy Western treaty regimes.Lets you pair U S Progressive mobilization with Japan’s Meiji Department of Divinities in the same global moment when religion vs. state becomes a diplomatic template.

Mini-bridge you can drop in <400 words

Between 1870 and 1945 American churches completed the move Taylor calls the Age of Mobilization: Protestants bureaucratized social care (Social-Gospel settlement houses), lobbied Congress as the Federal Council of Churches (1908), and even fractured into competing media-savvy subcultures (Fundamentalists, Pentecostal storefronts). In the same decades Jewish thinkers, scrambling for civic equality, re-cast Judaism as a religion rather than a people Jewish Book Council, while Meiji Japan coined shūkyō to satisfy Western treaty law.
The result was a world in which “religions” now functioned like professional NGOs, each claiming a discrete sphere (spiritual care, social services, moral lobbying) alongside business and state — setting the stage for the Cold-War spiritual-industrial complex you unpack next.

That bridge gives you:

  • One continuity thread (charismatic Pentecostals keep the revival DNA alive → 1960s).

  • One institutional thread (Social-Gospel + ecumenical councils pre-figure post-1945 political religion).

  • A cross-cultural validation point (Batnitzky + Meiji) for your claim that categorizing religion peaks here.

What you asked for next

  • Deeper pull-quotes & page refs from:

    • Taylor, A Secular Age, ch. 12 “Age of Mobilization”

    • Batnitzky, How Judaism Became a Religion (intro + chap. 3 on emancipation)

    • Rauschenbusch, Christianity and the Social Crisis (1907)

  • If that’s the package you want, say “Yes, send the Progressive-Era source bundle” and I’ll generate a citation-rich dossier similar to the Awakening chapter. Otherwise, point me back to Moonism or Mormonism and we’ll switch tracks.

You said:
You've convinced me that the Progressive Era stuff is actually very important. But I want an overview of Charles Taylor's narrative of church as birthright to age of mobilization to whatever the heck he thought came after the age of mobilization. I've read the book. All I'll say is what he thought came at the end felt kind of nebulous and incomprehensible and non-persuasive, but I want to know if I might have just been not informed enough to be able to do it properly.
ChatGPT said:

Below is a road-map through Charles Taylor’s big arc in A Secular Age—from “church-as-birthright” to the Age of Mobilization and then to his contested finale, the Age of Authenticity. I flag the chapters, the sociological moves he thinks happen, and why many readers find the last stage both suggestive and slippery.

1. Birth-right Christendom (≈ 1500 → 1800)

Taylor’s languageWhat he means
“Ancien Régime / Confessional Age”Europe’s state churches—Lutheran kingdoms, Catholic monarchies, Puritan colonies—where religious identity is given at birth, enforced by law, and fused with civic membership. Dissent equals sedition.
Key featuresParish monopoly, sacral kingship, communal rituals that “merge the sacred canopy with the political dome.” Ordinary people don’t “choose” faith; they inherit it.
Why it cracksReformation pluralism → wars of religion → Enlightenment critique → growing literacy & mobility create, in Taylor’s phrase, “public spaces of reason outside clerical control.”

2. The Age of Mobilization (≈ 1800 → 1960)

What changes

  • Voluntary membership replaces birthright. Churches, parties, unions, temperance lodges all learn to recruit, discipline, and lobby like mass movements.

  • Nation-building & moral regulation. Catholics, mainline Protestants, evangelical “Bible Christians,” even secular socialists each forge tight sub-cultures that try to own the public square—think Catholic Action in France, the Kaiser’s Kulturkampf, the Federal Council of Churches in the U S. Laisvė

  • **Religious identity hardens into a bounded “denomination.” One now chooses (or is mobilised into) a church as one chooses a party. Taylor’s point: this is when our modern habit of speaking about multiple “religions” as parallel NGOs reaches full flower.

Why Taylor calls it mobilization

Because every tradition—Christian, secular, nationalist—builds bureaucratic machines to marshal citizens’ loyalty: seminaries, party newspapers, scouting leagues, settlement houses. The age is activist, moralizing, often imperial, and it still takes for granted a shared public moral order, even if rival groups disagree about whose order wins.

3. The Age of Authenticity (≈ 1960 → today)

Taylor’s claim

  • The 1960s cultural revolutions break the mobilization machines. Mass parties decline; churches lose monopoly over rites of passage; authority migrates from institutions to the self.

  • What people now seek is “authenticity”—living true to one’s own inner moral sources (a concept indebted to Romantic expressivism).

  • Religion doesn’t vanish; it pluralizes and privatizes: yoga class, Taizé chants, evangelical praise bands, New Age crystals, militant atheism—all coexist inside what Taylor calls the “immanent frame.”

Why readers find it nebulous

  • Taylor himself admits the Age of Authenticity is “less tidy”: it’s marked by cross-pressures—simultaneous pulls toward flattening secular immanence and toward new forms of transcendence.

  • Instead of a single grand narrative, we get multiple trajectories:

    • “Pilgrim quests” (spiritual seekers),

    • “Fragilized faith” (churchgoers aware of live secular options),

    • “Boosters of immanence” (hard secular humanists).
      These do not resolve into one epochal structure the way Mobilization did, hence the feeling of vagueness.

Taylor’s chapter layout

Book PartChapterEpoch tag
IV12Age of Mobilization Laisvė
  13Age of Authenticity Wikipedia
V14-20“Religion Today,” “The Immanent Frame,” “Cross-Pressures,” “Dilemmas,” “Conversions.” These unpack the messy, overlapping spiritual landscapes after 1960.

4. How this helps your book

  1. Progressive-Era fit – The U S. Social-Gospel bureaucracies, YMCA/YWCA, fundamentalist media empires: classic Age-of-Mobilization phenomena.

  2. Cold-War chapter – Vereide’s Fellowship, Unification Church, Opus Dei all weaponize the mobilization toolkit for anti-communism—exactly Taylor’s storyline extending into geopolitics.

  3. 1960s New Age → Internet spirituality – Your later chapters on charisma, neo-pagan appropriation, and online polytheism illustrate Taylor’s Authenticity age: expressive, individualized, suspicious of big institutions.

If you want deeper precision

Ask for a Taylor source-pack and I can pull:

  • Book page ranges where he defines each age (e.g., pp. 423-472 on Mobilization; 473-504 on Authenticity).

  • Key quotations (e.g., “the retreat of Christendom,” “culture of expressive individualism,” “cross-pressures of immanence”).

  • Secondary commentary (Smith, McCarraher, Wilken) critiquing the vagueness of Authenticity.

Just say “Send the Taylor source-pack.”

You said:

It feels, I mean, but what does he think about the places in Europe and, the places in Europe and Latin America where basically church membership isn't really strictly enforced as the birthright, but there basically is a monopoly on it. Does he think that that just simply doesn't exist, and these places, is there something that I'm missing with those places, or is it something else? Okay, yeah, um.
ChatGPT said:

How Taylor handles “soft-monopoly” Catholic zones in Europe & Latin America

1. They’re still part of the Age of Mobilization
Taylor’s “mobilization” type is not limited to plural-denomination societies. It names any context where identity has to be actively organized—through lay sodalities, missions, party machines, Catholic schooling, Marian confraternities—even if one confession still dominates the census.

  • • In chapter 12 he points to nineteenth-century France, Belgium, Ireland, Bavaria, Québec and much of Latin America, where bishops and politicians built “ghettos” of cradle Catholics: separate unions, newspapers, scouts, credit unions, football clubs, etc. Laisvė

  • • Because the old sacral order is gone, leaders must “persuade, push, dragoon, or bully” the faithful into disciplined practice— temperance rallies, Sacred-Heart crusades, Catholic Action militias. That coordination effort is precisely what earns the label mobilization Laisvė.

2. Birth-right nominalism vs. mobilized militancy
Taylor contrasts two Catholic majorities:

Pre-1800 ChristendomPost-1800 Mobilization bloc
Baptism and feast-days are taken for granted; parish and state overlap; little lay activism.The same population must be re-recruited and policed—missions, devotional leagues, Christian-Democrat parties. Participation now looks voluntary even if social pressure is intense.

Thus places like rural Spain or Chile circa 1900 sit half in the old “neo-Durkheimian” parish world, half in a new partisan culture that prints membership cards and sends delegates to Rome. Taylor warns against putting an entire society in one slot; instead we track how the weight of Christendom habits vs. mobilization tactics shifts over time Laisvė.

3. Why secularization later feels “sudden” there
Because mobilized Catholic monopolies lasted longer, the break—often after Vatican II—looks like a cliff-edge: Québec in the 1960s, Spain after 1975, Ireland after 1990. Taylor treats those collapses as late transitions from mobilization to what he calls the Age of Authenticity (the culture of expressive individualism). The timetable just runs two or three decades behind the North Atlantic Protestant world.

4. Latin America
He rarely details it, but his brief passes on Brazil or Mexico follow the Québec template: oligarchic Christendom → 1930s lay mobilization (Catholic Action, cristero aftermath) → 1970s liberation fronts → 1990s charismatic Catholic and Pentecostal competition. All that activity sits inside the mobilization box until charismatic/pentecostal individualism signals the authenticity turn.

Bottom line
Taylor doesn’t deny the existence of Catholic monopolies; he reclassifies them:

As soon as bishops, parties or movements must work to keep the flock, we have left the birth-right order—even if 95 % of babies are still baptized.

What comes after depends on how quickly those mobilization structures unravel. Where they hold (e.g., Poland), society can look “mobilized” well into the 21st century; where they implode (Ireland), the Age of Authenticity rushes in almost overnight.
